poem:
The Laughter of Ancestors

In the stories of our elders,
where mirth arises like dawn,
the bones of our spirits are warmed.
We lean into the past,
a circle of smiles
binding us,
the strength of survival
in every laugh,
a testament to being,
a shared echo
in the hollow of the land.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘We’re really funny people’: Native American director Erica Tremblay on Lily Gladstone, laughter for survival and breaking Hollywood When Erica Tremblay was a small child she would watch her aunts and uncles making everyone laugh with their storytelling. “I noticed this physical shift in the audience, where people would lean in. And I thought, I want that power. I want to be a person that has other people leaning in.” Among the Seneca Cayuga Nation,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
